awd_titl_txt: CC* Integration: End-to-End Software-Defined Cyberinfrastruture for Smart Agriculture and Transportation
awd_abstract_narration:
Imaging and other sensor-based understanding of plant behavior is becoming key
to new discoveries in plant genotypes leading to more productive and environment-friendly farming.
Similarly, distributed sensing is seen as a key component of a safe, efficient, and sustainable autonomous transportation systems.
Existing research and education in agriculture and transportation systems are constrained by the lack of connectivity between field-deployed testbed equipment and computing infrastructure. To realize that connectivity, this project proposes to deploy CyNet wireless networks to
connect experimental science testbeds to high-performance cloud computing infrastructures.

The CyNet project will:
1) deploy Predictable, Reliable, Real-time, and high-Throughput (PRRT) wireless networking solutions using the standards-compliant, open-source Open Air Interface software framework and commodity Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) hardware;
2) integrate these wireless networks with software defined networks to seamlessly integrate outdoor cameras, sensors, and autonomous vehicles, and connect these components to high performance cloud computing systems;
3) implement an infrastructure virtualization system that partitions CyNet into programmable, isolated experiments; and
4) create an infrastructure management system that performs admission and access control and establishes specified resource allocation policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Image processing- and other sensor-based understanding of plant behavior has become key to new discoveries in plant genotypes leading to a more productive and environment-friendly farming. Similarly, connectivity and autonomy are two main drivers of a safe, efficient, and sustainable transportation vision, and real-world study of connected and automated vehicles is a key tool towards realizing that vision. Existing research and education in agriculture and transportation systems are constrained by the lack of connectivity between field-deployed equipment and cloud infrastructures. To fulfill this gap, the CyNet cyberinfrastructure has been established at Iowa State University (ISU) to connect sensors and cameras in crop research farms as well as field-deployed vehicles to cloud computing infrastructures. In particular, CyNet features advanced, field-deployed wireless networks with open-source hardware and software platforms, software-defined optical networks, and high-performance cloud computing infrastructures. To serve as a software-defined, shared-use infrastructure, CyNet employs a whole-stack virtualization system to partition the end-to-end cyberinfrastructure into programmable, isolated slices, and it employs an infrastructure management system that performs admission and access control and decides specific resource allocation policies.

CyNet represents a first-of-its-kind endeavor of applying open-source wireless systems (e.g., USRP software-defined radio and OpenAirInterface 5G software) to field research use, and it has demonstrated the technical feasibility and inspired the development of the ARA wireless living lab for rural broadband (see arawireless.org). CyNet has enabled field prototyping and pilot of advanced wireless solutions, and it has enabled transformative plant science studies which promise to move agriculture into a new era in which inputs are optimized, farmer profitability is increased, production levels are less variable from year to year, and the ecological foot-print of agriculture is minimized. CyNet has enabled interdisciplinary education activities across computer networking, agriculture, and transportation, and it has enabled the development of a new graduate course on cyber-physical networking. CyNet has also helped engage under-represented students in STEM education.  

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2023
Modified by: Hongwei Zhang
